title: Worked Solution
text:
To find the equation of the line that passes through the points $$(-5,2)$$ and $$(2,2)$$, we can use the point-slope form of the equation of a line. The point-slope form is:
$$y-y1=m(x-x1)$$
where (x1,y1) is a point on the line, and $$m$$ is the slope of the line.
To find the slope, we can use the formula:
$$m= rac{y2-y1}{x2-x1}$$
Plugging in the coordinates of the two points we are given, we get:
$$m= rac{2-2}{2-\left(-5ight)}$$
$$m= rac{0}{7}$$
$$m=0$$
Since the slope is $$0$$, the line is horizontal. Any point on the line will have the same y-coordinate as the given points. So, we can use either of the given points to find the equation of the line.
Using the point $$(-5,2)$$, we get:
$$y-2=0(x-(-5))$$
$$y=2$$
So, the equation of the line is: $$y=2$$
